Meet Tilly

Tilly is a real-life bionic teen. At only 15 months old, Tilly had both of her hands amputated at the wrist because of a very rare infection. For years she used basic silicon arms, but in 2018 she became the first child in the UK to have bionic arms. These high-tech, 3D printed arms give Tilly a much fuller range of movement. In class, you will watch a video about Tilly, who is now a model, public speaker and make-up vlogger. In the video, Tilly showcases her colorful arm cases, before applying a full face of make-up - and trying out a new look.

This video has over 2.2M views on YouTube!

While watching the video, think about how Tilly controls her bionic arm.

After watching the video, write down as many questions as possible on the sticky notes your teacher gives you. These will form a Driving Question board for you to refer to at any time through this unit.

How does Tilly control her bionic arms?

Drag the following tile into your workspace and answer the question:
What challenges might come up if you were using bionic arms?

Now, choose one challenge you came up with and think how to address it. This is the first step of the engineering design process. This step is called a “Need Statement.” Your statement should be in the following format (drag and drop the following prompt into your workspace and revise it):
“People using a bionic arm need X in order to do Y.”

Creating a diagram or a flowchart

Next, let’s dive deeper into how bionic arms work.

Create a diagram or a flowchart that explains how you think Tilly is controlling her bionic arms.

You can create the diagram or flowchart on paper or a whiteboard, or in a ‘Sketch’ drawing tile here in CLUE.

Be sure to add anything you think is important to how Tilly controls the bionic arms.

Think about how the bionic arm is connected to Tilly’s body and what Tilly needs to do to make the bionic arm move.

If you worked on paper or a whiteboard, take a picture of your work and upload it to your workspace in an ‘Image’ tile.

To help you develop the model, you can read more about Tilly and her bionic arms here .

Reflection

At the end of the activity, please record your current thinking and learning in your Learning journal (see Reflection tab).
